name.text: Evaluating Cube Roots of Complex Numbers

questiontext.text:
Find the three cube roots of  \(z={@z_real@} + {@z_imag@}i\). Give all roots using principal argument!

Note: Write \(z\) in exponential form first using its principal argument, and the three square roots of \(z\) in trigonometric form.
Recall that \(\sqrt[n]{r}\) is entered as \(r^{1/n}\).

r = [[input:ans1]]  and \(\theta\) = [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]]

z = [[input:ans3]][[validation:ans3]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

[[ comment ]] TODO: Use EqualComAssRules for ans3 after server upgrade. [[/ comment ]]

(b) The three cube roots of \(z\) in trigonometric are;

\(z_{0}\) = [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

\(z_{1}\) = [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

\(z_{2}\) = [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]

[[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

Find the three square roots of \(z={@z_real@} {@if z_imag<0 then "-" else "+"@} {@ev(abs(z_imag),simp)@}i\). Give all roots using principal argument!.

Note: Write \(z\) in exponential form first using its principal argument, and the three square roots of \(z\) in trigonometric form.
Recall that \(\sqrt[n]{r}\) is entered as \(r^{1/n}\).

Recall that if \(z=x+iy\), \(r = |z| = \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}\) and depending on the quadrant in which your complex number lies, \(\theta\) is obtained from \(\tan^{-1}(y/x)\).

[[ if test="quadrant=0" ]]

In this case, your complex number lies in the first quadrant where \(\tan^{-1}(y/x) = {@arg@}\)  . 

[[ elif test="quadrant=1" ]]

In this case, your complex number lies in Quadrant 2 where  \(\tan^{-1}(y/x) = -{@angle@}\)  and \(\theta = \pi+(-{@angle@}) = {@arg@}\). 

[[ elif test="quadrant=2" ]]

In this case, your complex number lies in Quadrant 3 where  \(\tan^{-1}(y/x) = {@angle@}\)  and \(\theta = \pi+{@angle@} = {@arg@}\). 

[[ else ]]

In this case, your complex number lies in Quadrant 4 where  \(\tan^{-1}(y/x) = -{@angle@}\)  and \(\theta = 2\pi+(-{@angle@}) = {@arg@}\). 

[[/ if]]

So \(r = {@radius@}\) and \(\theta = {@ta2@}\) and hence in  exponential form, \(z=\displaystyle {@radius@} e^{i({@arg@})}\).

 

We apply the following formula to get the roots, \( z_{k}= \displaystyle |z|^{@1/n@}e^{({@Theta/n@}+{@2*k*%pi/n@})i}\) where \(n=3\), and \(k=0,1,2\). So,

\( \begin{align} z_{k}= \displaystyle {@radius@}^{@1/3@}e^{({@ev(ta2/3,simp)@}+{@2*k*%pi/3@})i} \end{align} \)

\( \begin{align} \text{For} \; & k=0, & \displaystyle z_{0}= \displaystyle {@ev(radius^(1/3),simp)@} e^{{@arg4@}i}={@ev(radius^(1/3),simp)@} \left( \cos({@arg4@}) + i \sin({@arg4@}) \right) \\ \text{For} \; & k=1, & \displaystyle z_{1}= \displaystyle {@ev(radius^(1/3),simp)@} e^{{@arg5@}i} = {@ev(radius^(1/3),simp)@} \left( \cos({@arg5@}) + i \sin({@arg5@}) \right) \\ \text{For} \; & k=2, & \displaystyle z_{2}= \displaystyle {@ev(radius^(1/3),simp)@} e^{{@arg6@}i} = {@ev(radius^(1/3),simp)@} \left( \cos({@arg6@}) + i \sin({@arg6@}) \right) \end{align} \)

questionnote.text:
\(z={@z_real@} + {@z_imag@}i\).

\(r = {@ta1@} \) and \( \theta = {@ta2@} \)

\( z = {@radius*%e^(arg*%i)@} \)

The three cube roots of \(z\) in trigonometric are;

\(z_{0} = {@ta4@} \)

\(z_{1} = {@ta4@} \)

\(z_{2} = {@ta4@} \)

falsefeedback.text: Check that you have calculated the value of \(r\) correctly.
Check that you have correctly measured the angle from the positive real axis.

truefeedback.text: Your values for r and \(\theta\) are incorrect, but you have correctly written the polar form using these values.

falsefeedback.text: Your values for r and \(\theta\) are correct, but you have not correctly written the polar form for the number. Check your syntax!

truefeedback.text: You found all three roots! You get full marks.
You got two out of three correct. Way to go!! You get 2/3 marks
You got one out of three correct. Nice attempt. You get 1/3 marks
It looks like your polar form was incorrect, but based on it, you managed to compute the cube roots of your polar form correctly.
